Engineering

We don’t have “a philosophy,” but here are some

semi-coherent thoughts on how we do things

View Open Positions
Check out our engineering blog
  • Overview
  • Tools
  • Open Source
  • Gettting Hired

There’s a balance between getting things done and getting things right

We understand that. Our focus is on quickly delivering reliable software. That means we commit to building features and infrastructure we need, but we try to avoid building things we only might need, and we don’t chase huge refactors that don't meaningfully improve our software.

Our best ideas have come from a few people scribbling on a whiteboard

We're build collaboratively. Our succcess comes from operating as a team, not one person staring bleary-eyed at Vim.

Code should be expressive and easy to reason about

We believe code is written for humans, not machines. At Spring, every line of code is reviewed by a human before it’s committed. Code review isn’t just quality control, it's an opportunity to discuss ideas, provide feedback, and learn from the code of others. We always want to be better engineers.

A beautiful product is more important than a beautiful codebase

We know code can be beautiful, but in the end, the user experience is what matters most to us.

Tools

We believe in using the right tools for the right jobs.

In our experience the right tool is often one you already have.

  • Go
  • Postgres
  • React (Front-end web)
  • Objective C (iOS)
  • Java (Android)
  • ElasticSearch
  • Python (machine learning)
  • Docker
  • AWS
  • Memcached

Getting Hired

We try to determine whether Spring is right for the engineer, not just whether the engineer is right for Spring.

We don't hire unicorns, rockstars, ninjas, 10xers, etc. We hire strong engineers that we look forward to working with every day.

We aren't sadists. An interview shouldn't be an interrogation.

Everyone gets treated with respect.
